title: Your iPhone battery can last longer with this new iOS 26 feature
description: iOS 26 has a new Adaptive Power feature that can ensure your iPhone battery lasts as long as possible without giving up much performance.
content:
Battery life is easily one of the iPhone’s most important features. Whether you’re planning to buy the ultra-thin iPhone 17 Air, the battery beast iPhone 17 Pro Max, or hold on to your current model, iOS 26 has a new feature coming that can make your iPhone’s battery last longer: Adaptive Power.

Adaptive Power is a new iOS 26 setting to extend battery life

If your iPhone battery is getting low, iOS has long offered Low Power Mode as a helpful tool.

While I’ve heard of some users keeping Low Power Mode on all the time, that’s a pretty extreme option to stretch your iPhone’s battery life.

iOS 26 has a much more moderate solution.

Adaptive Power is a brand new battery setting that can ensure your iPhone lasts longer—particularly on the high-usage days.

You can find it inside the Settings app’s Battery menu under ‘Power Mode.’

Unlike Low Power Mode, which deactivates lots of features and noticeably degrades your experience, Adaptive Power is all about making small battery gains with minimal impact on performance.

Essentially, on a “normal use” day, your iPhone battery won’t necessarily be extended much—if at all.

But when you‘re using your iPhone more than usual, Adaptive Power will kick in and make minor adjustments to help stretch your battery longer.

Note: even though Apple doesn’t market Adaptive Power as an AI feature, users running the iOS 26 beta have found that it’s only available on Apple Intelligence-supported devices.

That means you’ll need an iPhone 16-class model or newer, or an iPhone 15 Pro or Pro Max.

Have you been using Adaptive Power in the iOS 26 beta? How’s it been working for you? Let us know in the comments.

summary: Apple's new iOS 26 feature, Adaptive Power, is a new setting that can extend the battery life of the iPhone. Unlike the use of Low Power Mode, Adaptic Power is a more moderate option to extend the life of your iPhone battery, focusing on making small battery gains with minimal impact on performance. The feature is only available on Apple Intelligence-supported devices.
shortSummary: Apple's new iOS 26 feature Adaptive Power can extend iPhone battery life with minimal battery impact, allowing users to use more frequently and sustain battery life.

Next month, the iPhone lineup is getting a brand new model: the iPhone 17 Air. Per various reports, Apple plans to drop its Plus option in favor of an ultra-thin new form factor that could tempt a lot of Pro users. Here are seven features coming to the iPhone 17 Air.
Ultra-thin form factor
Following the trend started by Apple’s M4 iPad Pro, the iPhone 17 Air’s defining feature will be its thinness.
Per Ming-Chi Kuo and various other reports, iPhone 17 Air will be just 5.55mm thin. Presumably, this measurement does not include the camera bar.
This is a massive reduction from current iPhones. The 16 Pro models are 8.25mm thick, while the base 16 and 16 Plus are 7.8mm.
Apple’s thinnest model ever was the iPhone 6, and even that was 6.9mm.
New 6.6-inch display
Being ultra-thin won’t be the 17 Air’s only hardware advantage over the Pro line. Apple will also give its new model a unique display that could offer the perfect compromise between existing sizes.
Apple’s iPhone 17 Pro and Pro Max will feature 6.3-inch and 6.9-inch displays, respectively. These are the same sizes as the 16 Pro line.
iPhone 17 Air, however, will slot in exactly halfway between the two models with a 6.6-inch display. Thanks to its ultra-thin form factor, the 17 Air’s display may still feel small enough for current Pro users while offering just enough space to satisfy Pro Max fans too.
Always On and high refresh rate features
Ever since 2022, a big difference between Apple’s entry models and Pro line has involved two display features:
- Pro models boast an Always On display
- they also support the 120Hz ProMotion high refresh rate
These are the kind of features that, once you get used to them, are hard to go without.
Fortunately, for the first time, Always On and a version of ProMotion are expected to hit the base iPhone 17 and 17 Air.
I say ‘a version of’ because rumors have swirled about a possible 90Hz refresh rate display being in the works at Apple. No credible rumor has indicated this will hit the 17 Air, so it’s likely it will get the full 120Hz ProMotion feature.
A19 Pro chip
Apple giving a new chip to its latest iPhone is always a given. But iPhone 17 Air chip rumors are especially intriguing.
For a while, consensus was that the base iPhone 17 and 17 Air would get an A19 chip, while the 17 Pro and Pro Max alone get A19 Pro.
Recently though, a leaker suggested Apple is putting the A19 Pro in the iPhone 17 Air too—but with one GPU core disabled.
How much difference will there ultimately be between these various A19 chips? Probably not a lot for everyday tasks.
New design with single rear 48MP camera and four colors
As seen in the dummy models above, the iPhone 17 Air is expected to differ from its siblings substantially in the design and camera departments.
While the 17 Pro line again offers three rear cameras, and the base model two, the 17 Air will feature only one: the main 48MP ‘Fusion’ camera.
Rumors have been minimal around this camera’s features, which could indicate it will be very similar to the existing main camera on the iPhone 16 line.
As for the rest of the design, expect four color options:
- Black
- Silver
- Light Gold
- Light Blue
24MP front camera
Currently, the iPhone’s selfie camera is only 12MP—and gets clearly inferior results to the rear cameras.
Fortunately, Apple is bringing a welcome 24MP upgrade to the front camera on the iPhone 17 Air and all other iPhone 17 models.
The new front camera is still unlikely to match the quality of the rear camera, but it should at least close the gap substantially.
Apple’s in-house C1 modem
Finally, there’s a connectivity change coming to the iPhone 17 Air that could help boost battery life a bit.
Apple’s in-house C1 modem debuted earlier this year in the iPhone 16e, bringing several benefits including a battery improvement.
Out of the full iPhone 17 lineup, only the iPhone 17 Air will get the new C1 modem.
iPhone 17 Air features: wrap-up
The iPhone 17 Air will no doubt be the most exciting fourth model in Apple’s lineup to date. Where the iPhone mini and Plus had their niche groups of loyal fans, the 17 Air seems likely to set the future tone for iPhone design. It’s going to be a fun iPhone 17 launch season.
Which iPhone 17 Air features are you most excited about? Do you plan to buy the new model? Let us know in the comments.

Apple Intelligence is one of the most exciting and powerful new technologies Apple has launched of late. It is now available—with a beta label—as part of iOS 18.3, macOS Sequoia 15.3, and iPadOS 18.3. Here is the full list of devices that support Apple Intelligence.
iPhones
- iPhone 16e
- iPhone 16

- iPad mini (A17 Pro)
Apple Intelligence features
Apple has released its AI features gradually across several software releases.
The first wave of AI features included language tools for AI to analyze your writing and offer revisions in various writing styles, or simply proofread for grammar and spelling. Another early feature was notification summaries, which make notifications more actionable than ever. There are also summary tools in Mail, Safari, and Messages.
The first steps of an upgraded Siri also arrived on supported Apple Intelligence devices in iOS 18.1 and 18.2. Some of its most advanced capabilities, though, won’t debut until later in iOS 18.4 and beyond. These include on-screen awareness, cross-app actions, and personal context awareness.
Top comment by Nozuka
Don't buy first gen they said... yet the M1 Air is still going strong :)
Apple Intelligence also offers image tools for creating original images via a simple typed description. These include a new Image Playground app and Genmoji.
No Vision Pro, Apple Watch, or HomePod support
Apple Intelligence currently requires a compatible iPhone, Mac, or iPad. No other Apple devices support the new technology.
Vision Pro support is reportedly in the works, and perhaps new HomePod models will be powerful enough to host the new Siri. There’s no official support for Apple Intelligence on Apple Watch either, though the Watch does benefit from a couple key AI features.
It’s likely that a few years from now, Apple Intelligence will pervade every product Apple sells. But for now, only select iPhones, iPads, and Macs support it.

In just one month, Apple will unveil its full iPhone 17 lineup. The brand new Air model will get a lot of attention, but Apple also has big changes coming for iPhone 17 Pro Max. I’m tentatively planning to buy a 17 Air, but there are three Pro Max features in particular that could make Apple’s premium iPhone hard to resist.
#1: Anti-reflective display
I love a sunny day. More so than the average person, my mood depends heavily on how much sunshine there is, and my ability to get out and enjoy the sun.
So I became very excited by the rumor that iPhone 17 Pro and Pro Max will pack a new, anti-reflective display.
Depending on how much of a difference Apple’s anti-reflective tech makes, I could see this feature being hugely influential in my iPhone purchase decision.
For days in the sun, an iPhone 17 Pro Max with anti-reflective display would be fantastic. Plus, I’d be able to keep brightness cranked up due to this next feature.
#2: Biggest battery ever
Battery anxiety, for me at least, has mostly become a thing of the past. Last year’s iPhone 16 Pro brought enough battery improvements that even on the most demanding days, I’ve rarely needed to worry about charging up.
iPhone 17 Pro Max is expected to improve things even further. Even though Apple’s Pro Max model always offers the best battery life, this year’s 17 Pro Max is getting thicker than ever to pack an even bigger battery.
Even though I’ve been leaning toward an iPhone 17 Air this year, battery struggles on the iOS 26 beta have me second-guessing that choice. I’m sure iOS battery performance will improve before the public launch. But the thought of getting the best battery life ever in an iPhone is now suddenly more appealing.
#3: Camera upgrades
iPhone cameras are at the point where they can be used to shoot major Hollywood blockbusters. Yet Apple continues making big and small improvements every single year.
With iPhone 17 Pro Max, there are potentially a lot of camera upgrades coming. Two solid bets:
- 24MP TrueDepth front facing camera (up from 12MP)
- 48MP Telephoto lens (up from 12MP)
Top comment by Bacon Bits
I'm all in for the anti reflective display and 8x optical zoom. The first feature has only been done by Samsung and I need more companies to hop on board. My Pixel 9 Pro XL doesn't have this and you can't even find a screen protector with the feature.
Outside of these sensor changes, which supply chain leaks have made all but certain, there are a variety of other possible improvements.
Rumors include: a second Camera Control button, multi-cam video recording, 8x optical zoom, and a pro camera app. None of these seem as solidly supported as the sensor changes, but they’re certainly possible.
Which iPhone 17 Pro Max features are you most excited about? Let us know in the comments.

Use Low Power Mode to save battery life on your iPhone or iPad
Low Power Mode temporarily reduces background activity on iPhones and iPads to extend battery life when the battery level gets low.
Turn Low Power Mode on or off from the Settings app
Open Settings.
Tap Battery.
Toggle the Low Power Mode switch on or off.
Additional ways to turn Low Power Mode on or off:
From Control Center: Swipe down from the top-right corner of your screen and tap the battery icon.
Ask Siri: Say "Siri, turn on Low Power Mode" or "Hey Siri, turn off Low Power Mode".
Low Power Mode extends the battery life of iPhones and iPads when the battery level gets low. Low Power Mode reduces the amount of power that the device uses by affecting certain features, such as:
5G: turned off on most devices, except for video streaming and large downloads on iPhone 12 and 13 models
Auto-Lock: defaults to 30 seconds
Display brightness: reduced
Display refresh rate: limited up to 60 Hz on iPhone and iPad models with ProMotion display
Visual effects: some effects are turned off
iCloud Photos: temporarily paused
Automatic downloads: turned off
Email fetch: turned off
Background app refresh: turned off
When Low Power Mode is active,
in the status bar turns yellow. Low Power Mode automatically turns off when the device is charged to 80% or higher.Learn more
iPhones with iOS 11.3 or later show battery health and recommend if a battery needs to be replaced. Find out more in iPhone Battery and Performance. You can also learn how to maximize battery life and lifespan.

argos_summary: Apple’s upcoming iOS 26 introduces Adaptive Power, a subtle battery‑saving mode that activates on high‑usage days and requires Apple‑Intelligence‑enabled devices such as iPhone 16‑class models. The company is also set to launch the iPhone 17 lineup next month, with the new ultra‑thin Air model featuring a 6.6‑inch display, 24‑MP front camera, and a single 48‑MP rear sensor, while the Pro and Pro Max variants promise anti‑reflective screens, larger batteries, and camera upgrades. Apple Intelligence, now beta‑available on select iPhones, Macs, and iPads, adds AI‑driven writing, notification, and image tools, but is not yet supported on Apple Watch, HomePod, or Vision Pro. Meanwhile, iOS 26’s Low Power Mode remains a manual battery‑saving option that reduces background activity and display performance when the battery is low. Together, these updates highlight Apple’s focus on extending battery life, enhancing camera and display technology, and integrating AI features across its ecosystem.
